title: Rustc builds forever due to infinite recursion error

labels.name: T-compiler
labels.description: Relevant to the compiler team, which will review and decide on the PR/issue.

labels.name: I-hang
labels.description: Issue: The compiler never terminates, due to infinite loops, deadlock, livelock, etc.

body:
<!--
Thank you for filing a bug report! 🐛 Please provide a short summary of the bug,
along with any information you feel relevant to replicating the bug.
-->

I tried this code:

```rust
struct Recurse {
    recurse: Recurse
}

enum AType {
    ARecurse(Recurse),
}

struct MyStruct {
    atype: AType,
}

fn main() {
    let x = MyStruct { atype: AType::ARecurse(Recurse{}) };
}

```

I expected to see this happen:
```
error[E0072]: recursive type `Recurse` has infinite size
 --> main.rs:1:1
  |
1 | struct Recurse {
  | ^^^^^^^^^^^^^^ recursive type has infinite size
2 |     next: Recurse
  |     ------------- recursive without indirection
  |
  = help: insert indirection (e.g., a `Box`, `Rc`, or `&`) at some point to make `Recurse` representable

error: aborting due to previous error

For more information about this error, try `rustc --explain E0072`.
```

Instead, this happened:
```
error[E0072]: recursive type `Recurse` has infinite size
 --> main.rs:1:1
  |
1 | struct Recurse {
  | ^^^^^^^^^^^^^^ recursive type has infinite size
2 |     next: Recurse
  |     ------------- recursive without indirection
  |
  = help: insert indirection (e.g., a `Box`, `Rc`, or `&`) at some point to make `Recurse` representable

```
Rustc never aborts. It gets stuck in compilation limbo.
